text: Photo by Chris Liverani on UnsplashНачнем с базисных определений.Акция (Share/Stock) — фактически это кусочек компании. Купили акцию компании — мы владеем маленьким кусочком бизнеса.Рыночная капитализация (Market Cap) компании — это ее цена на рынке. Вычисляется как цена одной акции помноженная на количество акций.ПримерКомпания выпустила 100М (сто миллионов) акций. Часть из них удерживается самой компанией, владельцами, инвесторами и т.д., а часть идет в продажу.Купля и продажа осуществляется на специальном рынке акций: на Бирже Акций (Stock Exchange).Допустим текущая цена акции (Share price): $100 за штуку, значит рыночная капитализация компании: $100･100М = $10B (10 миллиардов $). Цена акции может меняться в течении дня, например из-за спекуляции на рынке, соответсвенно плавает и цена всей компании.Если на цену компании влияет спекуляция и временные факторы, как узнать реальную стоимость компании? Как сравнить две компании? У них разное количество акций, и разная цена! Что вообще можно сказать о цене акции? Дорого/дёшево?Вспомним, что акция представляет часть бизнеса, а бизнес — это что то долговременное и менее подвержено спекуляциями. Бизнес имеет прибыль, расход, оборот, клиентов, продукт и т.д. Вот на это и имеет смысл опираться. К сожалению количество Фундаментальных Параметров настолько огромно, что анализ акций и бизнесов — это полноценная работа, причём далеко не факт что прибыльная. Очень много также зависит от удачи.Давайте рассмотрим несколько примеров.Допустим наша компания имеет годовую прибыль (Earnings): $500M. Хороше это или плохо?Один из самых главных фундаментальных параметров — это: Price/Earnings Ratio. Вычисляется следующим образом:P/E Ratio = Market Capital / EarningsВ нашем случает это будет: $10B / $500М = 20.P/E Ratio = 20 — означает что компания заработала за год 20-ую часть от своей поной стоимости. Много это или мало? Хороший вопрос, но теперь мы можем сравнивать две компании, у которых похожий бизнес. Чем выше P/E Ratio, тем компания более переоценена, чем ниже — тем компания более недооценена. Исторически коэффициент в пределах 15–20 считается нормальным. Если выше — дорого, если ниже — дешево.Кажется совсем просто, но к сожалению это не так. В каждой сфере бизнеса, коэффициент может иметь немного разный диапазон “нормальности”. Например в Хай-тек, коэффициент может быть значительно выше и инвесторов это не сильно пугает.Что бы не мучаться с количеством акций и огромными числами, обычно глобальные параметры компании переводят в параметры за одну акцию:Earnings per share = $500M / 100М = $5 — прибыль на одну акцию.P/E Ratio = Share price / Earnings per share = $100 / $5 = 20 — так гораздо проще!Что компания может сделать с заработанным капиталом? Она может пустить деньги в развитие и дальнейший рост, а может выплатить дивиденды (частично).Допустим компания решила выплатить акционерам дивиденды: $2 на каждую акцию. Т.е. имеем:Dividend yield per share = $2.Соответственно в процентом отношении это будет:Dividend yield = Dividend yield per share / Share Price ･ 100%.Для нашей компании — это будет: $2 / $100 ･ 100% = 2%. Значит если мы инвестировали $10000 в акции компании, то нам выплатят 2% или $200 дивидендов в год. Некоторые компании платят 4% и выше в виде дивидендов.Обычно дивиденды платят по квартально, иногда и помесячно. Есть компании, которые вообще не платят дивидендов, а есть которые стараются увеличивать дивиденды из года в год.Заметим что высокие дивиденды в процентном соотношении не обязательно означает что это хорошо. Может оказаться что по какой то причине (спекуляции?) цена акции упала, соответственно процент дивидендов поднялся.Можно ли угадать потенциально хорошие компании с сильным ростом? К сожалению это очень сложно, те кто будут утверждать обратное, как минимум самоуверенны, а как максимум мошенники. Вот примеры компаний и их рост.Начиная с 2005 года, весь рынок акций вырос в 3 раза, т.е., если б мы инвестировали $10K во весь рынок, то сейчас имели бы $30K. Неплохо.Но если б мы купили акции “Waste Management” или “Starbucks Corporation”, то сейчас у нас было бы: $54K или $55K соответственно.На компаниях Boeing и Google мы бы заработали $102K и $122K.Но на пицце (“Domino’s Pizza Inc”): $294K.На акциях Амазон — аж $402K!Не знаю можно ли предвидеть такое постоянно, скоре речь об удаче.Еще несколько моментов с акциями отдельных компаний — их цена и риски.Цена одной акции Google на данный момент больше $1000, а Amazon — около $2000. Нужны высокие начальные накопления, что бы купить парочку таких дорогих акций.Также даже с лидерами рынка могут происходить неприятности, вспомним Facebook или Boeing (понимаю, очень цинично думать про цену акции, когда люди потеряли близких).Для инвесторов один из способов уменьшить риск — это диверсифицировать, т.е., купить акции десятка или сотни успешных компаний. Но во первых это будет безумно дорого. А во вторых, придется заплатить большие комиссионные за покупку (брокер будет счастлив).Биржа и индексыВ Америке существуют две биржи акций: New Yourk Stock Exchange и Nasdaq. На Nasdaq торгуют в основном акциями высоко-технологичных компаний.В мире есть много других бирж, каждая “большая” страна имеет свою биржу: Лондонская биржа, Японская, Московская, Тель-Авивская (Израиль тоже имеет биржу!), и т.д.Обычно акции национальных компании торгуются на своих национальных биржах, но не всегда конечно.Что бы иметь возможность отслеживать рост всего рынка, или отдельной отрасли, или биржи, уже очень давно были изобретены индексы. Вот примеры наиболее известных индексов:S&P-500 — примерно 500 самых больших компаний (по Market Cap).Nasdaq Composite — набор всех компаний, акции которых торгуются на бирже Nasdaq.Dow Jones Industrial Average — 30 самых больших компаний.Russell-1000 Index — набор из 1000 самых больших компаний.Для каждого из этих “корзин акций” высчитывают некоторое число (индекс), например: средняя цена всех акций в корзине. Само число не так важно, более важно растет индекс или падает!Насколько каждый из этих индексов представляет весь американский рынок?Например, S&P-500 покрывает 75% всего рынка акций и он уже очень точно отражает весь рынок т.е. его поведение коррелирует почти на 100% со всем рынком. Russell-1000 покрывает 90% всего рынка.И конечно есть более широкие индексы, покрывающие большее количество компании:Dow Jones U.S. Total Market Index — представляет 95% всего рынка.Russell-3000 Index — 3000 больших, средних и маленьких компаний, представляет 98% всего рынка.CRSP U.S. Total Market Index — около 4000 больших, средних и маленьких компаний.Wilshire 5000 Total Market Index — около 6000 компаний.Почему все это важно?Если угадывать на акциях могут только счастливчики (может им лучше играть в казино или лотерею?), то почему бы не инвестировать сразу в целый рынок? 15 лет назад мы могли инвестировать $10,000 в целый рынок и к сегодняшнему моменту могли получить $30,000 — не так уж и плохо! Это 8% роста в год!Еще один важный момент: “пассивное инвестирование” — доступно каждому!Совершенно не обязательно изучать каждый отчет компаний, понимать фундаментальные параметры, анализировать, тратить свое время. У каждого из нас есть профессия и переучиваться в трейдера (спекулянта) может быть очень дорого и по времени и по рискам.Каждый человек легко может стать инвестором потратив минимум времени, инвестировав во всю экономику Америки, или всего мира. Как это сделать — обсудим в теме про фонды.Заключение“Трейдинг” или “активное инвестирование” — требует как минимум понимания фундаментальных параметров компаний, а на самом деле много много удачи!“Пассивное инвестирование” во все компании одновременно уменьшает риски и требует минимум наших усилий. Долгосрочное инвестирование также уменьшает налоги и комиссионные брокерам.Конечно риск есть всегда, может наступить очередной кризис, экономика может уйти вниз, акции упадут на 50% и много чего плохого может случиться. Но если посмотреть на исторические данные, после спада, всегда был подъем и на отрезке в 10 и более лет, инвесторы были в плюсе.Графики доходности компаний: “Waste Management”, “Domino Pizza”, “Amazon”, в сравнении с S&P-500Доходность и рискиPortfolio VisualizerWritten bySlava ChernoyFollowStock MarketStock ExchangeStock Market IndexIndex FundsPassive InvestingMore from Slava ChernoyFollowMore From MediumIndex Funds: Simple Investing with Complex ImplicationsDavid L.E in Data Driven InvestorDonald Trump Won, No Matter What Happens NextJessica Wildfire in The Apeiron Blog(Why) There Was no Biden Landslideumair haque in Eudaimonia and CoThe Election Should Never Have Been This Closeumair haque in Eudaimonia and Co20 Things Most People Learn Too Late In LifeNicolas Cole in Better AdviceThis Is ‘I Wish a Motherf*cker Would’ Week for Black PeopleMarley K. in ZORAI Worked the Polls in Trump Country — and Left More Confused Than EverAaron Gell in GEN“Anyone but Bernie”, They Said.Lauren Martinchek in Dialogue & DiscourseAboutHelpLegalGet the Medium app

title: what is this stock exchange?what it does?
text: what is this stock exchange?what is this stock exchange?one of the pertinent question a lot of people ask at times is what is this stock exchange? what kind of stock do they exchange at the stock exchange? let’s address this one this time a stock exchange would literally mean a place where buyers and sellers meet and the exchange shares.why is it so relevant and why stock exchange is so important in life?stock exchange is extremely important because it gives marketability or liquidity to the shares of a company. imagine if there were no stock exchange and if a person who is holding shares of certain companies had to sell, he would only have an option to go back to a promoter and say please take these shares and give back my money. promoter would have already put that money into some project and he wouldn’t be in a position to repay.read here also: “why price of share go up and down in the share market ?thus stock exchange solves two major problems:1. if an investor wants to exit the company or sell off his shares stock exchange would find a buyer for him.2. without a platform it would be very difficult for a buyer and a seller to meet where they would want to exchange those shares and an agreed price on a particular day.read more about it here..Written byBiz stalker#business #education #knowledge #inspiration visit our website: bizstalker.comFollow50 50 50 Stock ExchangeStock MarketShare Market TipsInvestmentMoneyMore from Biz stalkerFollow#business #education #knowledge #inspiration visit our website: bizstalker.comMore From MediumQuestions You Need To Answer Before Achieving FIREKatrina Di in The Post-Grad Survival GuideTaking Back My Buying PowerAnna Franceschi4 Things to Do Instead of Watching Your 401(k) Balance Drop | The Motley FoolStaff in The Motley Fool25: MoneyCaroline LampinenIf You Want To Be Happy, SimplifyMai Mislang in The StartupHow To Pay Yourself When Cash Flow Is RandomSophia Sunwoo in The StartupHow to Balance Money in a RelationshipBen Le Fort in Making of a MillionaireThe Art of Art Investment: Introduction to the Art World as a BuyerThe Roxy Art MarketAboutHelpLegalGet the Medium app

Но во первых это будет безумно дорого. А во вторых, придется заплатить большие комиссионные за покупку (брокер будет счастлив).Биржа и индексыВ Америке существуют две биржи акций: New Yourk Stock Exchange и Nasdaq. Как сравнить две компании? У них разное количество акций, и разная цена! Что вообще можно сказать о цене акции? Дорого/дёшево?Вспомним, что акция представляет часть бизнеса, а бизнес — это что то долговременное и менее подвержено спекуляциями. Бизнес имеет прибыль, расход, оборот, клиентов, продукт и т.д. Вот на это и имеет смысл опираться. К сожалению количество Фундаментальных Параметров настолько огромно, что анализ акций и бизнесов — это полноценная работа, причём далеко не факт что прибыльная. Очень много также зависит от удачи.Давайте рассмотрим несколько примеров.Допустим наша компания имеет годовую прибыль (Earnings): $500M. Много это или мало? Хороший вопрос, но теперь мы можем сравнивать две компании, у которых похожий бизнес. Чем выше P/E Ratio, тем компания более переоценена, чем ниже — тем компания более недооценена. Исторически коэффициент в пределах 15–20 считается нормальным. Например в Хай-тек, коэффициент может быть значительно выше и инвесторов это не сильно пугает.Что бы не мучаться с количеством акций и огромными числами, обычно глобальные параметры компании переводят в параметры за одну акцию:Earnings per share = $500M / 100М = $5 — прибыль на одну акцию.P/E Ratio = Share price / Earnings per share = $100 / $5 = 20 — так гораздо проще!Что компания может сделать с заработанным капиталом? Она может пустить деньги в развитие и дальнейший рост, а может выплатить дивиденды (частично).Допустим компания решила выплатить акционерам дивиденды: $2 на каждую акцию. Т.е. имеем:Dividend yield per share = $2.Соответственно в процентом отношении это будет:Dividend yield = Dividend yield per share / Share Price ･ 100%.Для нашей компании — это будет: $2 / $100 ･ 100% = 2%. Значит если мы инвестировали $10000 в акции компании, то нам выплатят 2% или $200 дивидендов в год. Некоторые компании платят 4% и выше в виде дивидендов.Обычно дивиденды платят по квартально, иногда и помесячно. Есть компании, которые вообще не платят дивидендов, а есть которые стараются увеличивать дивиденды из года в год.Заметим что высокие дивиденды в процентном соотношении не обязательно означает что это хорошо. Может оказаться что по какой то причине (спекуляции?) цена акции упала, соответственно процент дивидендов поднялся.Можно ли угадать потенциально хорошие компании с сильным ростом? К сожалению это очень сложно, те кто будут утверждать обратное, как минимум самоуверенны, а как максимум мошенники. Вот примеры компаний и их рост.Начиная с 2005 года, весь рынок акций вырос в 3 раза, т.е., если б мы инвестировали $10K во весь рынок, то сейчас имели бы $30K. Неплохо.Но если б мы купили акции “Waste Management” или “Starbucks Corporation”, то сейчас у нас было бы: $54K или $55K соответственно.На компаниях Boeing и Google мы бы заработали $102K и $122K.Но на пицце (“Domino’s Pizza Inc”): $294K.На акциях Амазон — аж $402K!Не знаю можно ли предвидеть такое постоянно, скоре речь об удаче.Еще несколько моментов с акциями отдельных компаний — их цена и риски.Цена одной акции Google на данный момент больше $1000, а Amazon — около $2000. Нужны высокие начальные накопления, что бы купить парочку таких дорогих акций.Также даже с лидерами рынка могут происходить неприятности, вспомним Facebook или Boeing (понимаю, очень цинично думать про цену акции, когда люди потеряли близких).Для инвесторов один из способов уменьшить риск — это диверсифицировать, т.е., купить акции десятка или сотни успешных компаний. Но во первых это будет безумно дорого. А во вторых, придется заплатить большие комиссионные за покупку (брокер будет счастлив).Биржа и индексыВ Америке существуют две биржи акций: New Yourk Stock Exchange и Nasdaq. На Nasdaq торгуют в основном акциями высоко-технологичных компаний.В мире есть много других бирж, каждая “большая” страна имеет свою биржу: Лондонская биржа, Японская, Московская, Тель-Авивская (Израиль тоже имеет биржу!), и т.д.Обычно акции национальных компании торгуются на своих национальных биржах, но не всегда конечно.Что бы иметь возможность отслеживать рост всего рынка, или отдельной отрасли, или биржи, уже очень давно были изобретены индексы. Вот примеры наиболее известных индексов:S&P-500 — примерно 500 самых больших компаний (по Market Cap).Nasdaq Composite — набор всех компаний, акции которых торгуются на бирже Nasdaq.Dow Jones Industrial Average — 30 самых больших компаний.Russell-1000 Index — набор из 1000 самых больших компаний.Для каждого из этих “корзин акций” высчитывают некоторое число (индекс), например: средняя цена всех акций в корзине. Само число не так важно, более важно растет индекс или падает!Насколько каждый из этих индексов представляет весь американский рынок?Например, S&P-500 покрывает 75% всего рынка акций и он уже очень точно отражает весь рынок т.е. его поведение коррелирует почти на 100% со всем рынком. Russell-1000 покрывает 90% всего рынка.И конечно есть более широкие индексы, покрывающие большее количество компании:Dow Jones U.S. Total Market Index — представляет 95% всего рынка.Russell-3000 Index — 3000 больших, средних и маленьких компаний, представляет 98% всего рынка.CRSP U.S. Total Market Index — около 4000 больших, средних и маленьких компаний.Wilshire 5000 Total Market Index — около 6000 компаний.Почему все это важно?Если угадывать на акциях могут только счастливчики (может им лучше играть в казино или лотерею?), то почему бы не инвестировать сразу в целый рынок? 15 лет назад мы могли инвестировать $10,000 в целый рынок и к сегодняшнему моменту могли получить $30,000 — не так уж и плохо! Это 8% роста в год!Еще один важный момент: “пассивное инвестирование” — доступно каждому!Совершенно не обязательно изучать каждый отчет компаний, понимать фундаментальные параметры, анализировать, тратить свое время. У каждого из нас есть профессия и переучиваться в трейдера (спекулянта) может быть очень дорого и по времени и по рискам.Каждый человек легко может стать инвестором потратив минимум времени, инвестировав во всю экономику Америки, или всего мира. Как это сделать — обсудим в теме про фонды.Заключение“Трейдинг” или “активное инвестирование” — требует как минимум понимания фундаментальных параметров компаний, а на самом деле много много удачи!“Пассивное инвестирование” во все компании одновременно уменьшает риски и требует минимум наших усилий. Russell-1000 покрывает 90% всего рынка.И конечно есть более широкие индексы, покрывающие большее количество компании:Dow Jones U.S. Total Market Index — представляет 95% всего рынка.Russell-3000 Index — 3000 больших, средних и маленьких компаний, представляет 98% всего рынка.CRSP U.S. Total Market Index — около 4000 больших, средних и маленьких компаний.Wilshire 5000 Total Market Index — около 6000 компаний.Почему все это важно?Если угадывать на акциях могут только счастливчики (может им лучше играть в казино или лотерею?), то почему бы не инвестировать сразу в целый рынок? 15 лет назад мы могли инвестировать $10,000 в целый рынок и к сегодняшнему моменту могли получить $30,000 — не так уж и плохо! Это 8% роста в год!Еще один важный момент: “пассивное инвестирование” — доступно каждому!Совершенно не обязательно изучать каждый отчет компаний, понимать фундаментальные параметры, анализировать, тратить свое время. У каждого из нас есть профессия и переучиваться в трейдера (спекулянта) может быть очень дорого и по времени и по рискам.Каждый человек легко может стать инвестором потратив минимум времени, инвестировав во всю экономику Америки, или всего мира. Как это сделать — обсудим в теме про фонды.Заключение“Трейдинг” или “активное инвестирование” — требует как минимум понимания фундаментальных параметров компаний, а на самом деле много много удачи!“Пассивное инвестирование” во все компании одновременно уменьшает риски и требует минимум наших усилий. Долгосрочное инвестирование также уменьшает налоги и комиссионные брокерам.Конечно риск есть всегда, может наступить очередной кризис, экономика может уйти вниз, акции упадут на 50% и много чего плохого может случиться. Но если посмотреть на исторические данные, после спада, всегда был подъем и на отрезке в 10 и более лет, инвесторы были в плюсе.Графики доходности компаний: “Waste Management”, “Domino Pizza”, “Amazon”, в сравнении с S&P-500Доходность и рискиPortfolio VisualizerWritten bySlava ChernoyFollowStock MarketStock ExchangeStock Market IndexIndex FundsPassive InvestingMore from Slava ChernoyFollowMore From MediumIndex Funds: Simple Investing with Complex ImplicationsDavid L.E in Data Driven InvestorDonald Trump Won, No Matter What Happens NextJessica Wildfire in The Apeiron Blog(Why) There Was no Biden Landslideumair haque in Eudaimonia and CoThe Election Should Never Have Been This Closeumair haque in Eudaimonia and Co20 Things Most People Learn Too Late In LifeNicolas Cole in Better AdviceThis Is ‘I Wish a Motherf*cker Would’ Week for Black PeopleMarley K. in ZORAI Worked the Polls in Trump Country — and Left More Confused Than EverAaron Gell in GEN“Anyone but Bernie”, They Said.Lauren Martinchek in Dialogue & DiscourseAboutHelpLegalGet the Medium app

title: Examining Execution Stability at IEX
text: Individual executions are the fundamental units of trading, and the first step in executing a trade is identifying a plan. We can classify the strategies available to the trader into three broad categories based on what price they seek to execute at relative to the National Best Bid and Offer (NBBO)Spread-cross — e.g: buy a stock by lifting the offer, essentially giving up edge to the seller in return for immediacy and a high degree of certainty around the trade price.Spread-capture — e.g: try to buy a stock at the bid or less than the mid. This strategy is a slightly greedy one, as you’re looking for a deal relative to the best displayed offer. Of course, deal-seeking comes with additional risk of opportunity cost from not finding a willing counterparty.Compromise — e.g: try to buy a stock at the midpoint of the NBBO. Here you are not looking for the best possible price relative to the market but instead are trying to meet your counterparty halfway. Naturally, this option falls at a point between the previous two on the risk/reward curve.Using this simple framework comes with complications: not all executions within these categories are equal. For example, a midpoint trade that happens immediately before the midpoint changes is not the same kind of balanced compromise as a trade at the midpoint of a market that is not in transition¹.Execution stability is an important factor in evaluating how well the intent of a trading strategy is realized.At IEX, we believe that exchange design can play a big role in execution performance. Since our inception, we’ve focused on building technology designed to help traders avoid adverse selection and transact as intended relative to prices that are not imminently changing.And the data shows that we are successful in doing so.Stable Midpoint VolumeIn August 2020, 95.5% of IEX’s midpoint volume was executed in a stable market, defined as executions not occurring in the 2ms periods before NBBO changes. This compares to 74.8% for Nasdaq, 85.3% for EDGX, 78.9% for NYSE, 77.7% for Arca, and 75.8% for BATS.Calculated using Daily TAQ data from August 2020The main contributor to IEX’s market-leading level of stable midpoint volume is our Discretionary Peg order type (D-Peg). D-Peg orders benefit from IEX’s Speed Bump and our Crumbling Quote Indicator (i.e., the CQI or IEX Signal).The Speed Bump delays all incoming orders by 350 microseconds (μs) which is designed to give IEX time to determine the most up-to-date NBBO to which we should peg resting orders. The CQI goes further and tries to anticipate a changing NBBO before it happens, allowing resting D-Peg orders to avoid executing during these unstable moments.These two features are designed to work in tandem to enhance the stability of D-Peg trades, but it’s natural to wonder how they individually contribute to this performance. The following is one way to decompose their impact.Technology Tag-TeamConsider an incoming order that could potentially trade with a resting D-Peg order at IEX. The way this order interacts with the Speed Bump and CQI depends on the state of the market when the incoming order arrived.Consider the following cases:(Speed Bump-Protected) The incoming order arrives within 350μs after IEX sees an NBBO move. In this case, without the Speed Bump, we would have pegged a resting D-Peg order at an undesirable price (one that would have changed within 350μs). The 350μs window afforded by the Speed Bump allows IEX to price the D-Peg order at the midpoint of the newly established, current NBBO.(CQI-Protected) The incoming order arrives between 2ms before and 350μs after IEX sees an NBBO move AND following a correct CQI prediction. In this case, without the CQI, a D-Peg order could have executed at a midpoint that would be stale within 2ms. With the CQI functionality, the D-Peg order would stay booked 1 MPV outside the NBBO, where it is less likely to execute.(Unprotected) The incoming order arrives between 2ms before and 350μs after IEX sees an NBBO move WITHOUT a correct CQI prediction. When IEX is unable to anticipate an upcoming price change, an incoming counterparty has the potential to generate an execution at an unstable price.(Stable NBBO, no protection needed²) The incoming order doesn’t arrive in a (2ms before, 350μs after) window around an NBBO move. In this case, IEX doesn’t need to do anything special to execute at the intended pegged price, since it is not changing.Note that all marketable-to-mid orders fall within at least one of these cases. For orders that fall into more than one case, we’ll assign them using the priority: CQI-Protected > Speed Bump-protected > Unprotected > Stable.Scenario BreakdownThe following visualizations break down the count of incoming marketable-to-mid³ orders from August 2020 into the above four categories. Each vertical line represents the breakdown of an individual security. First, let’s look at a set of well-known symbols:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020The symbols are sorted by the percentage of orders in the “stable” category; you can see that across symbols, there is a diversity in the percentage of incoming orders received during a stable market.Some symbols, such as GOVT, rarely tick, and therefore most order arrival times are inherently stable and neither the Speed Bump nor CQI play a big role in helping Members trade at the midpoint in a stable market.Other tickers, such as AMZN, are thinly quoted with wide spreads, so the Speed Bump gives IEX the ability to observe the NBBO changes when they happen, while the CQI plays a small role⁴.Finally, there are some heavily quoted tickers, such as SPY, with more structured quote changes, where the CQI interacts with more incoming orders than the Speed Bump alone.Expanding our symbol universe to those that traded an average daily notional value of at least $50M over the month of August 2020, we see that this kind of diversity is widespread:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020The Speed Bump and the CQI’s relevance in preventing adverse selection varies across symbols, but it is the combination of these two technologies that allows us to raise the floor on all symbols by a significant degree. That is, without the Speed Bump or CQI, all of the counterparty orders outside the darkest-blue section could potentially generate unstable executions with our resting D-Peg orders.Another way to think about it is: if IEX did not have the Speed Bump or the CQI, the entire graphic above the darkest blue segment would be red.The Next Frontier in Stable ExecutionsBy appropriately filtering incoming orders across all symbols, the Speed Bump and CQI play a significant role in boosting IEX’s stable midpoint volume percentage to 95.5%.With stability so high, the natural question is: Where do we go from here?The answer is: to displayed trading. While IEX’s focus to this point has been on pegged (non-displayed) orders, displayed orders also experience significant levels of adverse selection.In fact, for the aggressive (spread-crossing) contra orders that are eligible to trade with displayed liquidity (a subset of the marketable-to-mid orders considered above), the diversity in the analogous four-category breakdown is even more dramatic. Since displayed limit orders are not pegged to the NBBO, we’ll discard the “speed-bump-protected” category — aggressive orders received in the windows surrounding NBBO changes will either need to be caught by the CQI, or they will count as “unprotected.”When we decompose aggressive orders into the three remaining categories by symbol, we see that the diversity across symbols is even greater. Here is the previously used set of well-known symbols:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020(This time, we sort by percentage of aggressive orders in the CQI-protected category). And here is the full set of symbols that traded an average daily notional value of at least $50M over the month of August 2020:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020You can see that, compared to counterparties at the midpoint, you have significantly fewer opportunities for a stable execution when your contra is an aggressive order. For most symbols, the fraction of stable contra-orders is less than 30%!However, notice that many of the unstable contra orders are anticipated by the CQI for a large portion of symbols. For example, in TWTR, just 28% of the spread-crossing counterparties arrived during a stable market. Of the remaining unstable orders, nearly 2/3 arrived following a CQI prediction! If we could prevent displayed limit orders from trading with these aggressive orders that were predicted by the CQI, we would have a chance at significantly reducing the number of unstable executions, allowing the orders to achieve true spread capture.On August 26, 2020, the SEC granted approval to IEX’s Discretionary Limit (D-Limit) order type, which expands the application of the CQI to displayed orders. We view this as a major innovation in displayed trading, and we’re excited to see how its introduction on October 1 affects the way market participants look for spread capture.IEX is optimistic that using CQI to reduce D-Limit’s executions during moments of instability will present a competitive option to resting displayed limit orders. We look forward to iterating on this new direction for displayed trading and continuing to develop innovative ways to provide high-quality executions for all market participants.[1] Similarly, buying at the bid is not really achieving true spread capture if that bid becomes the new offer from the NBBO spread shifting downward immediately after the execution. See: Who Ever Said Buy High and Sell Low for an in-depth discussion on how stability can cause the performance of the three categories to blend into each other.[2] As a probabilistic model, the CQI has the potential to “incorrectly” apply protection. False negatives and false positives could restrict a resting D-Peg order’s discretion in categories 3 + 4 respectively, preventing trades that might have been stable or even in the resting order’s favor. Despite the potential for these missed opportunities, IEX is able to trade more stable midpoint volume than any other exchange.[3] Marketable-to-mid meaning “priced at least as aggressively as the midpoint of the NBBO.” Such orders are eligible to transact with resting D-Peg orders.[4] In thinly-quoted names, there is often a single stock exchange at the NBB/NBO. As a result, quote changes are often atomic events that are less predictable. For more, see “lonely quotes” here.About IEX ExchangeIEX Exchange is a U.S. stock exchange designed to provide superior execution quality and set a new standard for trading. title: Increase your IPO Allotment Chances as a Retail Investor
text: With the decreasing interest rates in bank account deposits, post office deposits, ever-increasing prices of real estate, precious metals, and other “safe” investment tools, the population is slowly moving their investments towards the stock market.We all know, one of the easiest ways of getting good returns from the stock market is through IPOs(Initial Public Offerings). Companies usually target their IPOs at times of bull rally in the market, when there is high liquidity and people are struggling to find good stocks at reasonable prices. Hence, whenever there is an IPO of a fundamentally strong company coming up in the market, there is a lot of hype, and the IPO is heavily oversubscribed. Yes, there was crazy oversubscription for fundamentally good stocks(at the time of their IPOs) like IRCTC, SBI Cards, Happiest Minds, and a lot more.Most of us are left out with no allotment. However, there are a few tips and tricks that can be followed to increase your chances of allotment:Avoid Technical ErrorsThough most of the trading applications, Demat accounts are well built reactive web applications that help us to minimize human typing errors with their on the go validations, these points are still worth mentioning. Avoid errors in name, PAN number, bank details, etc. If you are applying through ASBA, double check your details like DP id, Demat account number, etc. Make sure the number of shares you apply for is a multiple of the defined number of shares per lot. Also, make sure you do not apply lesser or greater than the range of the number of shares allowed for Retail Investors.Maintain sufficient bank balance before allotmentSome banks block the amount which you are willing to spend to apply for the IPO. However, some do not block any amount and if you do not maintain adequate bank balance, your application will get rejected.One application per PAN numberWhether you have multiple Demat accounts or a single account, make sure that you apply for the IPO only once from just one of your Demat accounts. Multiple applications from one or many Demat accounts using the same PAN number will get all your applications rejected.Apply from multiple Demat accounts through different PAN numbersCreate Demat accounts in the name of your family members, relatives, or friends with their Demat account and you can make applications from their Demat accounts with their PAN numbers. Ensure it is still one application per PAN number.Always apply at the cut-off priceWhen IPOs are oversubscribed, they are going to come at the cut-off price. Avoid defining some price of your own to make sure your application is not rejected.Avoid application on the last day of the issueMost of the QIBs and FIIs and also the Retail Investors do their subscriptions on the last day of the issue based on the market sentiments. This means, there is a lot of load on the bank servers, trading application, etc. which may cause technical problems like UPI mandate notifications not coming up, OTP SMS not coming up, etc. which might make your application invalid. It is always better to apply before-hand, usually IPO sentiments on fundamentally strong companies do not change till the end of the issue date. However, if you have applied and you see that sentiments are looking bad, it may be possible to cancel your application.Apply for IPO allotment reservation quotaVery often, a good amount of shares are reserved for shareholders of the parent company, employees, etc. If you have that privilege, you can make use of it and increase your chances of allocation. You can even buy the parent company’s share for the short term(within the record date) and then apply for the IPO in the shareholder category. However, this technique may backfire if the parent company is highly favored in the market, in that case, there will be a higher number of people applying for the shareholder category and a lesser number of people in the unreserved category. Whether to apply this technique or not is based on the number of shares reserved for the reserved category and the parent company.Written byKunal KarmakarEnthusiastic Software EngineerFollowStock MarketIPOStock Market TipsInvestmentStock ExchangeMore from Kunal KarmakarFollowEnthusiastic Software EngineerMore From MediumHow to Survive on $800 a MonthKesia Alexandra in The StartupNew York’s Wack Pet Trust LawAndrea ColemanFree Financial Resources for Better Money in 2020Angely Mercado in Cheap AFStudent Loan Debt: A Sad State of the UnionThe Angry GradSharpe Ratio — Bigger Isn’t Necessarily BetterEng Guan Lim in Data Driven InvestorCan You Make A Living As a Day Trader?Jamie Murray in Understanding MoneyMonopoly: Board Game or Our Current Reality?Carter Kilmann in Bacon BitsInvestment Strategies from a Silicon Valley Hedge FundNathan Breiner in The AscentAboutHelpLegalGet the Medium app

title: STOCK EXCHANGE OR STOCK INDEX?
text: The Difference Between a Stock Exchange and a Stock IndexYou may hear talk about stock exchanges and stock indices, and it’s easy to confuse them as the same thing. In this article, we highlight what each means and show why they are relevant to your investing strategy. A stock index is a list of stocks that is created to gauge the whole market, or even a sector of the market. A stock exchange, on the other hand, is the actual place where you can buy and sell stocks, bonds, and other securities that are listed on different indices.Let’s look at some details below.Stock IndicesAn index groups together company stocks in order to measure changes in the broader stock market, or in a sector of the stock market. There are famous examples that you may have heard of, such as the FTSE100. This index includes the 100 largest companies in the UK.Indices can also exist for smaller companies, for example the Alternative Investment Market (AIM), which is a subsidiary of the London Stock Exchange and allows smaller companies to raise capital with less restrictions. Each index has its own measure of how exactly it’s valued. This could be based on the cumulative share price of the individual stocks, or it could be based on the total market capitalisation in the index. Some even combine both measurements. As the individual share prices or market caps move up and down within the index, the total value of the individual index changes too.Stock ExchangesIf you actually want to buy a stock, then you’ll have to turn to an exchange. One of the largest and most famous stock exchanges in the world is headquartered in the UK: the London Stock Exchange. There are exchanges all over the world, including the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Japan, the B3 in Brazil, and the New York Stock Exchange in the US. Whenever you go to place an order to buy or sell stocks, bonds, or other securities, the exchange will ultimately be involved in the transaction.Start today with as little as £10GET STARTEDWritten byWombatWombat allows people to invest in some of the world’s best-known brands for as little as £10.FollowStock ExchangeStock IndexFinanceMoneyInvestingMore from WombatFollowWombat allows people to invest in some of the world’s best-known brands for as little as £10.More From MediumAre You Making These 3 Mistakes With Your Health Savings Account?Jake Northrup, CFP®, CFA, CSLP®Leverage is a Balancing ActAnthony Andranik Moumjian in The StartupThe Relationship Between Risk and Return ExplainedChris Blackwell in DashVestA Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Investment Assets UniversePendora in The Startup3 Ways To Trick Your Brain To Stop Avoiding Financial DecisionsForbes in ForbesLife in a Low Interest Rate EnvironmentAvi Deutsch in Vodia CapitalFinancial Lessons As Taught By Game of ThronesAlicia Ho in The StartupHere’s How Daily Tracking Improves Your Mental Health & Wealth 💸Stephanie Claudia Goncalves in FinllectAboutHelpLegalGet the Medium app

title: Examining Execution Stability at IEX
text: Individual executions are the fundamental units of trading, and the first step in executing a trade is identifying a plan. We can classify the strategies available to the trader into three broad categories based on what price they seek to execute at relative to the National Best Bid and Offer (NBBO)Spread-cross — e.g: buy a stock by lifting the offer, essentially giving up edge to the seller in return for immediacy and a high degree of certainty around the trade price.Spread-capture — e.g: try to buy a stock at the bid or less than the mid. This strategy is a slightly greedy one, as you’re looking for a deal relative to the best displayed offer. Of course, deal-seeking comes with additional risk of opportunity cost from not finding a willing counterparty.Compromise — e.g: try to buy a stock at the midpoint of the NBBO. Here you are not looking for the best possible price relative to the market but instead are trying to meet your counterparty halfway. Naturally, this option falls at a point between the previous two on the risk/reward curve.Using this simple framework comes with complications: not all executions within these categories are equal. For example, a midpoint trade that happens immediately before the midpoint changes is not the same kind of balanced compromise as a trade at the midpoint of a market that is not in transition¹.Execution stability is an important factor in evaluating how well the intent of a trading strategy is realized.At IEX, we believe that exchange design can play a big role in execution performance. Since our inception, we’ve focused on building technology designed to help traders avoid adverse selection and transact as intended relative to prices that are not imminently changing.And the data shows that we are successful in doing so.Stable Midpoint VolumeIn August 2020, 95.5% of IEX’s midpoint volume was executed in a stable market, defined as executions not occurring in the 2ms periods before NBBO changes. This compares to 74.8% for Nasdaq, 85.3% for EDGX, 78.9% for NYSE, 77.7% for Arca, and 75.8% for BATS.Calculated using Daily TAQ data from August 2020The main contributor to IEX’s market-leading level of stable midpoint volume is our Discretionary Peg order type (D-Peg). D-Peg orders benefit from IEX’s Speed Bump and our Crumbling Quote Indicator (i.e., the CQI or IEX Signal).The Speed Bump delays all incoming orders by 350 microseconds (μs) which is designed to give IEX time to determine the most up-to-date NBBO to which we should peg resting orders. The CQI goes further and tries to anticipate a changing NBBO before it happens, allowing resting D-Peg orders to avoid executing during these unstable moments.These two features are designed to work in tandem to enhance the stability of D-Peg trades, but it’s natural to wonder how they individually contribute to this performance. The following is one way to decompose their impact.Technology Tag-TeamConsider an incoming order that could potentially trade with a resting D-Peg order at IEX. The way this order interacts with the Speed Bump and CQI depends on the state of the market when the incoming order arrived.Consider the following cases:(Speed Bump-Protected) The incoming order arrives within 350μs after IEX sees an NBBO move. In this case, without the Speed Bump, we would have pegged a resting D-Peg order at an undesirable price (one that would have changed within 350μs). The 350μs window afforded by the Speed Bump allows IEX to price the D-Peg order at the midpoint of the newly established, current NBBO.(CQI-Protected) The incoming order arrives between 2ms before and 350μs after IEX sees an NBBO move AND following a correct CQI prediction. In this case, without the CQI, a D-Peg order could have executed at a midpoint that would be stale within 2ms. With the CQI functionality, the D-Peg order would stay booked 1 MPV outside the NBBO, where it is less likely to execute.(Unprotected) The incoming order arrives between 2ms before and 350μs after IEX sees an NBBO move WITHOUT a correct CQI prediction. When IEX is unable to anticipate an upcoming price change, an incoming counterparty has the potential to generate an execution at an unstable price.(Stable NBBO, no protection needed²) The incoming order doesn’t arrive in a (2ms before, 350μs after) window around an NBBO move. In this case, IEX doesn’t need to do anything special to execute at the intended pegged price, since it is not changing.Note that all marketable-to-mid orders fall within at least one of these cases. For orders that fall into more than one case, we’ll assign them using the priority: CQI-Protected > Speed Bump-protected > Unprotected > Stable.Scenario BreakdownThe following visualizations break down the count of incoming marketable-to-mid³ orders from August 2020 into the above four categories. Each vertical line represents the breakdown of an individual security. First, let’s look at a set of well-known symbols:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020The symbols are sorted by the percentage of orders in the “stable” category; you can see that across symbols, there is a diversity in the percentage of incoming orders received during a stable market.Some symbols, such as GOVT, rarely tick, and therefore most order arrival times are inherently stable and neither the Speed Bump nor CQI play a big role in helping Members trade at the midpoint in a stable market.Other tickers, such as AMZN, are thinly quoted with wide spreads, so the Speed Bump gives IEX the ability to observe the NBBO changes when they happen, while the CQI plays a small role⁴.Finally, there are some heavily quoted tickers, such as SPY, with more structured quote changes, where the CQI interacts with more incoming orders than the Speed Bump alone.Expanding our symbol universe to those that traded an average daily notional value of at least $50M over the month of August 2020, we see that this kind of diversity is widespread:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020The Speed Bump and the CQI’s relevance in preventing adverse selection varies across symbols, but it is the combination of these two technologies that allows us to raise the floor on all symbols by a significant degree. That is, without the Speed Bump or CQI, all of the counterparty orders outside the darkest-blue section could potentially generate unstable executions with our resting D-Peg orders.Another way to think about it is: if IEX did not have the Speed Bump or the CQI, the entire graphic above the darkest blue segment would be red.The Next Frontier in Stable ExecutionsBy appropriately filtering incoming orders across all symbols, the Speed Bump and CQI play a significant role in boosting IEX’s stable midpoint volume percentage to 95.5%.With stability so high, the natural question is: Where do we go from here?The answer is: to displayed trading. While IEX’s focus to this point has been on pegged (non-displayed) orders, displayed orders also experience significant levels of adverse selection.In fact, for the aggressive (spread-crossing) contra orders that are eligible to trade with displayed liquidity (a subset of the marketable-to-mid orders considered above), the diversity in the analogous four-category breakdown is even more dramatic. Since displayed limit orders are not pegged to the NBBO, we’ll discard the “speed-bump-protected” category — aggressive orders received in the windows surrounding NBBO changes will either need to be caught by the CQI, or they will count as “unprotected.”When we decompose aggressive orders into the three remaining categories by symbol, we see that the diversity across symbols is even greater. Here is the previously used set of well-known symbols:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020(This time, we sort by percentage of aggressive orders in the CQI-protected category). And here is the full set of symbols that traded an average daily notional value of at least $50M over the month of August 2020:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020You can see that, compared to counterparties at the midpoint, you have significantly fewer opportunities for a stable execution when your contra is an aggressive order. For most symbols, the fraction of stable contra-orders is less than 30%!However, notice that many of the unstable contra orders are anticipated by the CQI for a large portion of symbols. For example, in TWTR, just 28% of the spread-crossing counterparties arrived during a stable market. Of the remaining unstable orders, nearly 2/3 arrived following a CQI prediction! If we could prevent displayed limit orders from trading with these aggressive orders that were predicted by the CQI, we would have a chance at significantly reducing the number of unstable executions, allowing the orders to achieve true spread capture.On August 26, 2020, the SEC granted approval to IEX’s Discretionary Limit (D-Limit) order type, which expands the application of the CQI to displayed orders. We view this as a major innovation in displayed trading, and we’re excited to see how its introduction on October 1 affects the way market participants look for spread capture.IEX is optimistic that using CQI to reduce D-Limit’s executions during moments of instability will present a competitive option to resting displayed limit orders. We look forward to iterating on this new direction for displayed trading and continuing to develop innovative ways to provide high-quality executions for all market participants.[1] Similarly, buying at the bid is not really achieving true spread capture if that bid becomes the new offer from the NBBO spread shifting downward immediately after the execution. See: Who Ever Said Buy High and Sell Low for an in-depth discussion on how stability can cause the performance of the three categories to blend into each other.[2] As a probabilistic model, the CQI has the potential to “incorrectly” apply protection. False negatives and false positives could restrict a resting D-Peg order’s discretion in categories 3 + 4 respectively, preventing trades that might have been stable or even in the resting order’s favor. Despite the potential for these missed opportunities, IEX is able to trade more stable midpoint volume than any other exchange.[3] Marketable-to-mid meaning “priced at least as aggressively as the midpoint of the NBBO.” Such orders are eligible to transact with resting D-Peg orders.[4] In thinly-quoted names, there is often a single stock exchange at the NBB/NBO. As a result, quote changes are often atomic events that are less predictable. title: Increase your IPO Allotment Chances as a Retail Investor
text: With the decreasing interest rates in bank account deposits, post office deposits, ever-increasing prices of real estate, precious metals, and other “safe” investment tools, the population is slowly moving their investments towards the stock market.We all know, one of the easiest ways of getting good returns from the stock market is through IPOs(Initial Public Offerings). Companies usually target their IPOs at times of bull rally in the market, when there is high liquidity and people are struggling to find good stocks at reasonable prices. Hence, whenever there is an IPO of a fundamentally strong company coming up in the market, there is a lot of hype, and the IPO is heavily oversubscribed. Yes, there was crazy oversubscription for fundamentally good stocks(at the time of their IPOs) like IRCTC, SBI Cards, Happiest Minds, and a lot more.Most of us are left out with no allotment. However, there are a few tips and tricks that can be followed to increase your chances of allotment:Avoid Technical ErrorsThough most of the trading applications, Demat accounts are well built reactive web applications that help us to minimize human typing errors with their on the go validations, these points are still worth mentioning. Avoid errors in name, PAN number, bank details, etc. If you are applying through ASBA, double check your details like DP id, Demat account number, etc. Make sure the number of shares you apply for is a multiple of the defined number of shares per lot. Also, make sure you do not apply lesser or greater than the range of the number of shares allowed for Retail Investors.Maintain sufficient bank balance before allotmentSome banks block the amount which you are willing to spend to apply for the IPO. However, some do not block any amount and if you do not maintain adequate bank balance, your application will get rejected.One application per PAN numberWhether you have multiple Demat accounts or a single account, make sure that you apply for the IPO only once from just one of your Demat accounts. Multiple applications from one or many Demat accounts using the same PAN number will get all your applications rejected.Apply from multiple Demat accounts through different PAN numbersCreate Demat accounts in the name of your family members, relatives, or friends with their Demat account and you can make applications from their Demat accounts with their PAN numbers. Ensure it is still one application per PAN number.Always apply at the cut-off priceWhen IPOs are oversubscribed, they are going to come at the cut-off price. Avoid defining some price of your own to make sure your application is not rejected.Avoid application on the last day of the issueMost of the QIBs and FIIs and also the Retail Investors do their subscriptions on the last day of the issue based on the market sentiments. This means, there is a lot of load on the bank servers, trading application, etc. which may cause technical problems like UPI mandate notifications not coming up, OTP SMS not coming up, etc. which might make your application invalid. It is always better to apply before-hand, usually IPO sentiments on fundamentally strong companies do not change till the end of the issue date. However, if you have applied and you see that sentiments are looking bad, it may be possible to cancel your application.Apply for IPO allotment reservation quotaVery often, a good amount of shares are reserved for shareholders of the parent company, employees, etc. If you have that privilege, you can make use of it and increase your chances of allocation. You can even buy the parent company’s share for the short term(within the record date) and then apply for the IPO in the shareholder category. However, this technique may backfire if the parent company is highly favored in the market, in that case, there will be a higher number of people applying for the shareholder category and a lesser number of people in the unreserved category. Whether to apply this technique or not is based on the number of shares reserved for the reserved category and the parent company.Written byKunal KarmakarEnthusiastic Software EngineerFollowStock MarketIPOStock Market TipsInvestmentStock ExchangeMore from Kunal KarmakarFollowEnthusiastic Software EngineerMore From MediumHow Do We Measure Investment Performance?Farhad Malik in FinTechExplainedYou never forget the time when you were poorKelly Tompkins in The Startup3 Ways to Build Income Streams (Right Now)Envy Writer in Not Poor AnymoreThe Cruelest Social Experiment in the History of MoneyRocco Pendola in Making of a Millionaire3 Reasons Why You Can’t Save MoneyRocco Pendola in Making of a MillionaireDon’t Buy that Cup of CoffeeAaron Schnoor in The Intelligence of EverythingWhy Entrepreneurs Should Spend Time Earning a Passive IncomeCalendar in CalendarYou Don’t Need a Budget, You Just Need These Two AccountsKelley C. title: STOCK EXCHANGE OR STOCK INDEX?
text: The Difference Between a Stock Exchange and a Stock IndexYou may hear talk about stock exchanges and stock indices, and it’s easy to confuse them as the same thing. In this article, we highlight what each means and show why they are relevant to your investing strategy. A stock index is a list of stocks that is created to gauge the whole market, or even a sector of the market. A stock exchange, on the other hand, is the actual place where you can buy and sell stocks, bonds, and other securities that are listed on different indices.Let’s look at some details below.Stock IndicesAn index groups together company stocks in order to measure changes in the broader stock market, or in a sector of the stock market. There are famous examples that you may have heard of, such as the FTSE100. This index includes the 100 largest companies in the UK.Indices can also exist for smaller companies, for example the Alternative Investment Market (AIM), which is a subsidiary of the London Stock Exchange and allows smaller companies to raise capital with less restrictions. Each index has its own measure of how exactly it’s valued. This could be based on the cumulative share price of the individual stocks, or it could be based on the total market capitalisation in the index. Some even combine both measurements. As the individual share prices or market caps move up and down within the index, the total value of the individual index changes too.Stock ExchangesIf you actually want to buy a stock, then you’ll have to turn to an exchange. One of the largest and most famous stock exchanges in the world is headquartered in the UK: the London Stock Exchange. There are exchanges all over the world, including the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Japan, the B3 in Brazil, and the New York Stock Exchange in the US. title: Examining Execution Stability at IEX
text: Individual executions are the fundamental units of trading, and the first step in executing a trade is identifying a plan. We can classify the strategies available to the trader into three broad categories based on what price they seek to execute at relative to the National Best Bid and Offer (NBBO)Spread-cross — e.g: buy a stock by lifting the offer, essentially giving up edge to the seller in return for immediacy and a high degree of certainty around the trade price.Spread-capture — e.g: try to buy a stock at the bid or less than the mid. This strategy is a slightly greedy one, as you’re looking for a deal relative to the best displayed offer. Of course, deal-seeking comes with additional risk of opportunity cost from not finding a willing counterparty.Compromise — e.g: try to buy a stock at the midpoint of the NBBO. Here you are not looking for the best possible price relative to the market but instead are trying to meet your counterparty halfway. Naturally, this option falls at a point between the previous two on the risk/reward curve.Using this simple framework comes with complications: not all executions within these categories are equal. For example, a midpoint trade that happens immediately before the midpoint changes is not the same kind of balanced compromise as a trade at the midpoint of a market that is not in transition¹.Execution stability is an important factor in evaluating how well the intent of a trading strategy is realized.At IEX, we believe that exchange design can play a big role in execution performance. Since our inception, we’ve focused on building technology designed to help traders avoid adverse selection and transact as intended relative to prices that are not imminently changing.And the data shows that we are successful in doing so.Stable Midpoint VolumeIn August 2020, 95.5% of IEX’s midpoint volume was executed in a stable market, defined as executions not occurring in the 2ms periods before NBBO changes. This compares to 74.8% for Nasdaq, 85.3% for EDGX, 78.9% for NYSE, 77.7% for Arca, and 75.8% for BATS.Calculated using Daily TAQ data from August 2020The main contributor to IEX’s market-leading level of stable midpoint volume is our Discretionary Peg order type (D-Peg). D-Peg orders benefit from IEX’s Speed Bump and our Crumbling Quote Indicator (i.e., the CQI or IEX Signal).The Speed Bump delays all incoming orders by 350 microseconds (μs) which is designed to give IEX time to determine the most up-to-date NBBO to which we should peg resting orders. The CQI goes further and tries to anticipate a changing NBBO before it happens, allowing resting D-Peg orders to avoid executing during these unstable moments.These two features are designed to work in tandem to enhance the stability of D-Peg trades, but it’s natural to wonder how they individually contribute to this performance. The following is one way to decompose their impact.Technology Tag-TeamConsider an incoming order that could potentially trade with a resting D-Peg order at IEX. The way this order interacts with the Speed Bump and CQI depends on the state of the market when the incoming order arrived.Consider the following cases:(Speed Bump-Protected) The incoming order arrives within 350μs after IEX sees an NBBO move. In this case, without the Speed Bump, we would have pegged a resting D-Peg order at an undesirable price (one that would have changed within 350μs). The 350μs window afforded by the Speed Bump allows IEX to price the D-Peg order at the midpoint of the newly established, current NBBO.(CQI-Protected) The incoming order arrives between 2ms before and 350μs after IEX sees an NBBO move AND following a correct CQI prediction. In this case, without the CQI, a D-Peg order could have executed at a midpoint that would be stale within 2ms. With the CQI functionality, the D-Peg order would stay booked 1 MPV outside the NBBO, where it is less likely to execute.(Unprotected) The incoming order arrives between 2ms before and 350μs after IEX sees an NBBO move WITHOUT a correct CQI prediction. When IEX is unable to anticipate an upcoming price change, an incoming counterparty has the potential to generate an execution at an unstable price.(Stable NBBO, no protection needed²) The incoming order doesn’t arrive in a (2ms before, 350μs after) window around an NBBO move. In this case, IEX doesn’t need to do anything special to execute at the intended pegged price, since it is not changing.Note that all marketable-to-mid orders fall within at least one of these cases. For orders that fall into more than one case, we’ll assign them using the priority: CQI-Protected > Speed Bump-protected > Unprotected > Stable.Scenario BreakdownThe following visualizations break down the count of incoming marketable-to-mid³ orders from August 2020 into the above four categories. Each vertical line represents the breakdown of an individual security. First, let’s look at a set of well-known symbols:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020The symbols are sorted by the percentage of orders in the “stable” category; you can see that across symbols, there is a diversity in the percentage of incoming orders received during a stable market.Some symbols, such as GOVT, rarely tick, and therefore most order arrival times are inherently stable and neither the Speed Bump nor CQI play a big role in helping Members trade at the midpoint in a stable market.Other tickers, such as AMZN, are thinly quoted with wide spreads, so the Speed Bump gives IEX the ability to observe the NBBO changes when they happen, while the CQI plays a small role⁴.Finally, there are some heavily quoted tickers, such as SPY, with more structured quote changes, where the CQI interacts with more incoming orders than the Speed Bump alone.Expanding our symbol universe to those that traded an average daily notional value of at least $50M over the month of August 2020, we see that this kind of diversity is widespread:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020The Speed Bump and the CQI’s relevance in preventing adverse selection varies across symbols, but it is the combination of these two technologies that allows us to raise the floor on all symbols by a significant degree. That is, without the Speed Bump or CQI, all of the counterparty orders outside the darkest-blue section could potentially generate unstable executions with our resting D-Peg orders.Another way to think about it is: if IEX did not have the Speed Bump or the CQI, the entire graphic above the darkest blue segment would be red.The Next Frontier in Stable ExecutionsBy appropriately filtering incoming orders across all symbols, the Speed Bump and CQI play a significant role in boosting IEX’s stable midpoint volume percentage to 95.5%.With stability so high, the natural question is: Where do we go from here?The answer is: to displayed trading. While IEX’s focus to this point has been on pegged (non-displayed) orders, displayed orders also experience significant levels of adverse selection.In fact, for the aggressive (spread-crossing) contra orders that are eligible to trade with displayed liquidity (a subset of the marketable-to-mid orders considered above), the diversity in the analogous four-category breakdown is even more dramatic. Since displayed limit orders are not pegged to the NBBO, we’ll discard the “speed-bump-protected” category — aggressive orders received in the windows surrounding NBBO changes will either need to be caught by the CQI, or they will count as “unprotected.”When we decompose aggressive orders into the three remaining categories by symbol, we see that the diversity across symbols is even greater. Here is the previously used set of well-known symbols:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020(This time, we sort by percentage of aggressive orders in the CQI-protected category). And here is the full set of symbols that traded an average daily notional value of at least $50M over the month of August 2020:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020You can see that, compared to counterparties at the midpoint, you have significantly fewer opportunities for a stable execution when your contra is an aggressive order. For most symbols, the fraction of stable contra-orders is less than 30%!However, notice that many of the unstable contra orders are anticipated by the CQI for a large portion of symbols. For example, in TWTR, just 28% of the spread-crossing counterparties arrived during a stable market. Of the remaining unstable orders, nearly 2/3 arrived following a CQI prediction! If we could prevent displayed limit orders from trading with these aggressive orders that were predicted by the CQI, we would have a chance at significantly reducing the number of unstable executions, allowing the orders to achieve true spread capture.On August 26, 2020, the SEC granted approval to IEX’s Discretionary Limit (D-Limit) order type, which expands the application of the CQI to displayed orders. We view this as a major innovation in displayed trading, and we’re excited to see how its introduction on October 1 affects the way market participants look for spread capture.IEX is optimistic that using CQI to reduce D-Limit’s executions during moments of instability will present a competitive option to resting displayed limit orders. We look forward to iterating on this new direction for displayed trading and continuing to develop innovative ways to provide high-quality executions for all market participants.[1] Similarly, buying at the bid is not really achieving true spread capture if that bid becomes the new offer from the NBBO spread shifting downward immediately after the execution. See: Who Ever Said Buy High and Sell Low for an in-depth discussion on how stability can cause the performance of the three categories to blend into each other.[2] As a probabilistic model, the CQI has the potential to “incorrectly” apply protection. False negatives and false positives could restrict a resting D-Peg order’s discretion in categories 3 + 4 respectively, preventing trades that might have been stable or even in the resting order’s favor. Despite the potential for these missed opportunities, IEX is able to trade more stable midpoint volume than any other exchange.[3] Marketable-to-mid meaning “priced at least as aggressively as the midpoint of the NBBO.” Such orders are eligible to transact with resting D-Peg orders.[4] In thinly-quoted names, there is often a single stock exchange at the NBB/NBO. As a result, quote changes are often atomic events that are less predictable. title: Increase your IPO Allotment Chances as a Retail Investor
text: With the decreasing interest rates in bank account deposits, post office deposits, ever-increasing prices of real estate, precious metals, and other “safe” investment tools, the population is slowly moving their investments towards the stock market.We all know, one of the easiest ways of getting good returns from the stock market is through IPOs(Initial Public Offerings). Companies usually target their IPOs at times of bull rally in the market, when there is high liquidity and people are struggling to find good stocks at reasonable prices. Hence, whenever there is an IPO of a fundamentally strong company coming up in the market, there is a lot of hype, and the IPO is heavily oversubscribed. Yes, there was crazy oversubscription for fundamentally good stocks(at the time of their IPOs) like IRCTC, SBI Cards, Happiest Minds, and a lot more.Most of us are left out with no allotment. However, there are a few tips and tricks that can be followed to increase your chances of allotment:Avoid Technical ErrorsThough most of the trading applications, Demat accounts are well built reactive web applications that help us to minimize human typing errors with their on the go validations, these points are still worth mentioning. Avoid errors in name, PAN number, bank details, etc. If you are applying through ASBA, double check your details like DP id, Demat account number, etc. Make sure the number of shares you apply for is a multiple of the defined number of shares per lot. Also, make sure you do not apply lesser or greater than the range of the number of shares allowed for Retail Investors.Maintain sufficient bank balance before allotmentSome banks block the amount which you are willing to spend to apply for the IPO. However, some do not block any amount and if you do not maintain adequate bank balance, your application will get rejected.One application per PAN numberWhether you have multiple Demat accounts or a single account, make sure that you apply for the IPO only once from just one of your Demat accounts. Multiple applications from one or many Demat accounts using the same PAN number will get all your applications rejected.Apply from multiple Demat accounts through different PAN numbersCreate Demat accounts in the name of your family members, relatives, or friends with their Demat account and you can make applications from their Demat accounts with their PAN numbers. Ensure it is still one application per PAN number.Always apply at the cut-off priceWhen IPOs are oversubscribed, they are going to come at the cut-off price. Avoid defining some price of your own to make sure your application is not rejected.Avoid application on the last day of the issueMost of the QIBs and FIIs and also the Retail Investors do their subscriptions on the last day of the issue based on the market sentiments. This means, there is a lot of load on the bank servers, trading application, etc. which may cause technical problems like UPI mandate notifications not coming up, OTP SMS not coming up, etc. which might make your application invalid. It is always better to apply before-hand, usually IPO sentiments on fundamentally strong companies do not change till the end of the issue date. However, if you have applied and you see that sentiments are looking bad, it may be possible to cancel your application.Apply for IPO allotment reservation quotaVery often, a good amount of shares are reserved for shareholders of the parent company, employees, etc. If you have that privilege, you can make use of it and increase your chances of allocation. You can even buy the parent company’s share for the short term(within the record date) and then apply for the IPO in the shareholder category. However, this technique may backfire if the parent company is highly favored in the market, in that case, there will be a higher number of people applying for the shareholder category and a lesser number of people in the unreserved category. Whether to apply this technique or not is based on the number of shares reserved for the reserved category and the parent company.Written byKunal KarmakarEnthusiastic Software EngineerFollowStock MarketIPOStock Market TipsInvestmentStock ExchangeMore from Kunal KarmakarFollowEnthusiastic Software EngineerMore From MediumHow to Survive on $800 a MonthKesia Alexandra in The StartupNew York’s Wack Pet Trust LawAndrea ColemanFree Financial Resources for Better Money in 2020Angely Mercado in Cheap AFStudent Loan Debt: A Sad State of the UnionThe Angry GradSharpe Ratio — Bigger Isn’t Necessarily BetterEng Guan Lim in Data Driven InvestorCan You Make A Living As a Day Trader?Jamie Murray in Understanding MoneyMonopoly: Board Game or Our Current Reality?Carter Kilmann in Bacon BitsInvestment Strategies from a Silicon Valley Hedge FundNathan Breiner in The AscentAboutHelpLegalGet the Medium app

title: STOCK EXCHANGE OR STOCK INDEX?
text: The Difference Between a Stock Exchange and a Stock IndexYou may hear talk about stock exchanges and stock indices, and it’s easy to confuse them as the same thing. In this article, we highlight what each means and show why they are relevant to your investing strategy. A stock index is a list of stocks that is created to gauge the whole market, or even a sector of the market. A stock exchange, on the other hand, is the actual place where you can buy and sell stocks, bonds, and other securities that are listed on different indices.Let’s look at some details below.Stock IndicesAn index groups together company stocks in order to measure changes in the broader stock market, or in a sector of the stock market. There are famous examples that you may have heard of, such as the FTSE100. This index includes the 100 largest companies in the UK.Indices can also exist for smaller companies, for example the Alternative Investment Market (AIM), which is a subsidiary of the London Stock Exchange and allows smaller companies to raise capital with less restrictions. Each index has its own measure of how exactly it’s valued. This could be based on the cumulative share price of the individual stocks, or it could be based on the total market capitalisation in the index. Some even combine both measurements. As the individual share prices or market caps move up and down within the index, the total value of the individual index changes too.Stock ExchangesIf you actually want to buy a stock, then you’ll have to turn to an exchange. One of the largest and most famous stock exchanges in the world is headquartered in the UK: the London Stock Exchange. There are exchanges all over the world, including the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Japan, the B3 in Brazil, and the New York Stock Exchange in the US.
